security_audit.summary: This skill is a pure markdown prompt file providing guidance for designing blockchain bots using the Silverback SDK. All static findings are false positives. The scanner misidentified standard blockchain terminology (keccak256, sha256, mainnet) as cryptographic weaknesses, CLI documentation as command injection, and documentation URLs as network exfiltration. The skill contains no executable code and advises best practices including using environment variables and circuit breakers for safety.

content.user_title: Create blockchain monitoring bots with Silverback
content.value_statement: Creating blockchain bots requires understanding event-driven architecture and risk management. This skill guides AI assistants to help users design, implement, and deploy automated bots that respond to on-chain events.
actual_capabilities: Guide users through blockchain bot design patterns
Explain event handling for blocks, logs, and cron triggers
Advise on risk management and circuit breakers
Describe state management for bot operations
limitations: Does not execute blockchain transactions directly
Requires user to install Silverback CLI separately
Does not provide pre-built bot templates
Does not access blockchain networks directly

prompt_templates.title: Simple event monitor
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a Silverback bot that listens for new blocks on Ethereum mainnet and logs block numbers and timestamps.

prompt_templates.title: Event filter bot
prompt_templates.scenario: User needs smart contract event monitoring
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a bot that watches for specific smart contract events on Uniswap and sends Discord notifications when trades occur.

prompt_templates.title: Risk-managed automation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a bot with circuit breaker protection and configurable limits via environment variables for automated trading.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-chain aggregator
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a bot that monitors multiple chains, tracks derived metrics, and triggers actions based on complex threshold conditions.

output_examples.input: Help me create a Silverback bot that monitors USDC transfers over 100,000
output: Use the Silverback App template with a Block handler or Event handler
Filter Transfer events where value > 100000 USDC
Add Telegram notification in the handler callback
Set environment variable for bot identity: SILVERBACK_APP_ID
Use print debugging first to verify event detection
Add a CircuitBreaker for emergency shutdown capability

output_examples.input: Design a bot that alerts me when a new pool is created on Uniswap
output: Use the Event handler to listen for PoolCreated events from the Uniswap factory contract
Set up filtering for the specific factory address you want to monitor
Configure Discord or Telegram notifications in the callback
Set SILVERBACK_APP_ID environment variable for identification
Start with monitoring mode before enabling any automated actions
Test thoroughly using a testnet like Sepolia first

output_examples.input: Create a trading bot with safety limits
output: Implement a CircuitBreaker that triggers when daily volume exceeds your limit
Use environment variables for all configuration: MAX_DAILY_VOLUME, MIN_PROFIT_THRESHOLD
Start in dry-run mode until you verify the logic works correctly
Only enable signing capabilities after thorough testing on testnet
Monitor all transactions via logs before going to production

best_practices: Start with print debugging before adding automated actions
Use environment variables for all configurable limits and keys
Implement circuit breakers for emergency stop conditions
Test thoroughly before configuring production signer keys
anti_patterns: Skipping documentation checks for current SDK version
Running bots with production keys before testing
Ignoring error logs during initial deployment
Hardcoding private keys or secrets in bot code

faq.question: Which blockchain networks does Silverback support?
faq.answer: Silverback supports any EVM-compatible network including Ethereum, Polygon, Arbitrum, and Optimism.

faq.question: What programming language is used for Silverback bots?
faq.answer: Silverback bots are written in Python using the Ape framework for blockchain interaction.

faq.question: How do I connect external services like Discord or Telegram?
faq.answer: Use Python client libraries in your event handlers to send messages via webhooks or bot APIs.

faq.question: Is it safe to run bots with signing capabilities?
faq.answer: Only after thorough testing. Use environment variables for keys and implement circuit breakers for safety.

faq.question: Why is my bot not receiving events?
faq.answer: Check network configuration, verify contract addresses, and review logs for connection or filter errors.

faq.question: How does this compare to other blockchain automation tools?
faq.answer: Silverback offers full Python flexibility for custom logic whereas alternatives may have limited scripting.
